title: Abbreviated Mental Test 4 (AMT-4)
description: Assesses mental impairment and cognitive function in elderly patients using four simple questions

parameters.name: date_of_birth
parameters.description: Patient correctly states their date of birth

parameters.name: place
parameters.description: Patient correctly identifies their current place/location

parameters.name: year
parameters.description: Patient correctly states the current year

result.name: amt_4_score
result.description: AMT-4 score ranging from 0 to 4 points

ranges.interpretation: Score <4 suggests significant cognitive impairment. Further detailed cognitive assessment recommended. Consider underlying causes such as delirium, dementia, or depression.
Score of 4/4 suggests normal cognitive function. No cognitive impairment detected on this brief screening test.

references: Swain DG, Nightingale PG. Evaluation of a shortened version of the Abbreviated Mental Test in a series of elderly patients. Clin Rehabil. 1997 Aug;11(3):243-8. doi: 10.1177/026921559701100308.
Hodkinson HM. Evaluation of a mental test score for assessment of mental impairment in the elderly. Age Ageing. 1972 Nov;1(4):233-8. doi: 10.1093/ageing/1.4.233.
Brooke P, Bullock R. Validation of a 6 item cognitive impairment test with a view to primary care usage. Int J Geriatr Psychiatry. 1999 Nov;14(11):936-40.
formula: Simple addition: 1 point for each correct answer (age + date_of_birth + place + year). Maximum score is 4 points.
notes: The AMT-4 is a shortened version of the original 10-item Abbreviated Mental Test (AMT-10)
Developed by Dr. David G. Swain as a quick cognitive screening tool for elderly patients
Particularly useful in emergency departments and acute care settings for rapid assessment
Score of 4/4 indicates normal cognitive function; score <4 suggests cognitive impairment
Should not be used as the sole diagnostic tool for dementia or other cognitive disorders
False positives may occur in patients with sensory impairments, language barriers, or severe illness
